channel.title: aleksati.net
channel.description: Part portfolio and part music technology blog. I write about audio programming, creative computing, software development and more.

item.title: Using the Kuramoto Model to Build a Multi-Channel Audio Synchronizer in Max
item.description: Almost two years ago, I built an audio DSP version of the Kuramoto model to sync metronomes for my digital rendition of 'Poème Symphonique for 100 Metronomes'. I have since written a post about this project, but looking back today, I feel like my Kuramoto model software deserves a post of its own, a post describing the process and how I designed it as a dynamic multi-channel audio object in Max, able to sync 100+ oscillators on the fly.

item.title: How Knowledge Distillation Can Optimize Neural Audio Effects and Distortion VSTs
item.description: Making neural networks smaller without harming their accuracy is difficult. Knowledge Distillation (KD) is a fairly new technique where larger models are used to train and improve the performance of smaller models. In this post, I walk through a recent research project where we examined if KD could enhance audio effects (VST) built with neural nets. And the short answer is yes, it can!

item.title: The Sun Right Now - Screensaver
item.description: The Sun Right Now is my new desktop screensaver that displays colorful 4K images of the sun in a cool slideshow. The images are retrieved directly from the NASA SDO, a satellite observatory currently orbiting Earth, in real-time. In this post, I share how the app works and how you can use it yourself. You can also check out an online browser demo of the app.

item.title: OSC Timestamps and Forward Synchronization in Python and Pure Data
item.description: OSC is a high-res protocol (64-bit) for sending messages between musical devices, similar to MIDI (8-bit). Last year, I led some workshops on OSC focusing on its unique networking capabilities. In this post, I present my workshops as a written step-by-step guide, showing how to use OSC Timestamps and a technique called Forward Synchronization to effectively sync musical devices in Python and Pure Data.

item.title: Strategies for Measuring Video Latency in Networked Music and Dance Performances
item.description: Measuring video latency in networked music performances (NMP) is stressful. There is little time and resources at hand, and on-site conditions often differ alot from controlled research setups. In this post, I share a few practical methods and strategies for measuring video latency that guarantee precise and reliable data collection in the field, developed from years of professional experience.

item.title: An Easy Way to Improve the Position of Studio Monitors
item.description: By improving the placement of your studio monitors, you can significantly improve the sound quality in your studio. In this post, I share an easy and practical way to find optimal placements for your studio monitors with just some basic tools and a little know-how.

item.title: Strategies for Measuring Audio Latency in Networked Music and Dance Performances
item.description: Measuring audio latency in networked music performances (NMP) is stressful. There is little time and resources at hand, and on-site conditions often differ alot from controlled research setups. In this post, I share a few practical methods and strategies for measuring audio latency that guarantee precise and reliable data collection in the field, developed from years of professional experience.

item.title: Audio Latency Examiner
item.description: A quick look into Audio Latency Examiner (ALEX); my new all-in-one software tool for measuring and batch collecting audio latency data from different software and hardware scenarios. The app is open-source and free to download, available for both Windows and Mac.

item.title: Dataset Generator for Musical Devices (DGMD)
item.description: the Dataset Generator for Musical Devices (DGMD) is software that can generate datasets from audio effects specifically for machine-learning tasks. This post takes a closer look at the DGMD software, including links to tutorials and download pages. Original post by Stefano Fasciani.

item.title: Poème Symphonique Numérique: Ligeti’s 100 Metronomes as Software
item.description: Modernist composer György Ligeti would have been 100 years in 2023. To celebrate, I dediced to create a version of his famous 'Poème Symphonique for 100 metronomes' in MaxMSP, using the Kuramoto model for synchronization and a real-time ML-based sound engine. Read more about my process, see the code and listen to the result here!

item.title: How to use p5js and p5-sounds with Nextjs in 2024
item.description: I sometimes use the p5js libraries to make little audio-visual widgets and sonification examples in my posts. Recently, I decided to re-design and update my p5 and p5-sounds implementation to support newer versions of p5, React, Nextjs (v14.1), and TypeScript. In this post, I share all my code and detail my process.

item.title: Things to Remember when Audio Engineering for Networked Music Performances
item.description: Mixing live sound for networked music events, where several locations are connected together in real-time, is very different from mixing in an average concert setting. Having to manage different stages through an added network layer can be a real challenge, especially when it's showtime and the pressure is on. In this post, I share some useful steps and strategies that can help improve your networked audio engineering practice.

item.title: Tools for Exploring Performance Patterns in Norwegian Folk Music
item.description: For my master thesis, I developed a series of interactive software tools to explore performance patterns in Hardanger Fiddle Music, in collaboration with the MIRAGE Research Project at UiO. This post takes a quick look at the software and its main features.

item.title: My Tiny MaxMSP Library for Audio, Video and Data Processing - alx.max
item.description: alx.max is my tiny library of MaxMSP abstractions for audio, video and data processing. It's an on-going effort to publish some of my Max code that I believe can be useful to others, and for me later on. All code and downloads are avaliable open-source.

item.title: Exploring Dataset Sonification with Web Audio
item.description: Thanks to modern browsers and open-source coding libraries, creating audio-visual art on the Web is easier than ever. In this post, I share some content from a workshop I recently held on ways to enhance data visualizations with model-based sonification in a browser using the p5js library. Interactive examples included!

item.title: 0101101000 ... (hello world)
item.description: 'Hello World' is a sound-sculpture made of burned drywall paper tape, methyl cellulose, aluminum flashing, bluetooth transducers, concrete and steel rods. The sculpture is made by artist Henrik Nordahl, but I was asked to make it sing, i.e generate sound and vibrations based on the WiFi traffic on-site. In this post I share what we did and how it turned out.

item.title: Using Python to Control Ableton Live with MIDI
item.description: While designing a new liveset, I wrote some Python code to help me map and navigate Ableton Live more efficiently using very few MIDI controls. Here is what I did and how.

item.title: 5G Networked Music Performances - Will it Work?
item.description: My collegue and I teamed up with Telenor Research to see if it's possible to play music together over next generation 5G networks. Here are the preliminary results from our first audio latency tests on private and commercial 5G networks.

item.title: Karwowski, Kann & Tidemann + Nordahl
item.description: An improvisational audio-visual quartet that offers thought-provoking and immersive concert experiences, combining guitar, vocals, live electronics, and projected visual art.

item.title: AudioVideoAnalysis - Realtime Spectral Analysis of Audio and Video
item.description: A quick look into AudioVideoAnalysis (v2.0); a standalone software tool for real-time OpenGL rendering of video motiongrams and audio spectrograms, developed in collaboration with FourMS Lab at the RITMO research center, University of Oslo.

item.title: VideoAnalysis - Analyzing Music-related Body Motion
item.description: A quick look into VideoAnalysis (v2.1); a beginners tool for analyzing music-related body motion, developed in collaboration with FourMS Lab at the RITMO research centre, University of Oslo.

item.title: Radio 9
item.description: A krautrock electronic pop trio from Oslo that takes you on a sonic journey from subtle electronic atmospheres to jarring post-punk whiteouts.

item.title: The Holy Mountain
item.description: The Holy Mountain is a dark synth-pop trio with accordion, vocals, synth and drums. Since 2015, the band has produced an impressive discography of critically acclaimed genre-defying music with a taste for the mysterious and transcendental.
